products.pregunta:
That is why she was so anxious to come, said Mrs. Norbury; she put off another engagement in order to accept my invitation. Shes had visions and dreams, and all those sort of things, that have come true in a most marvellous manner, but shes never actually seen a ghost, and shes longing to have that experience. She belongs to that Research Society, you know.

 I expect shell see the unhappy Lady Cullumpton, the most famous of all the Exwood ghosts, said Mrs. Dole; my ancestor, you know, Sir Gervase Cullumpton, murdered his young bride in a fit of jealousy while they were on a visit to Exwood.

 I daresay she wont see anything at all; she never has yet, you know, said Mrs. Norbury hopefully.

 The Norburys played bridge for the next three nights till nearly one oclock; they did not care for the game, but it reduced the time at their guests disposal for undesirable ghostly visitations.

 Miss Bleek is not likely to be in a frame of mind to see ghosts, said Hugo Norbury, if she goes to bed with her brain awhirl with royal spades and no trumps and grand slams.

 The precautions were in vain. On the third morning of her stay Ada Bleek came down late to breakfast, her eyes looking very tired, but ablaze with excitement, her hair done anyhow, and a large brown volume hugged under her arm.

 At last Ive seen something supernatural! she exclaimed, and gave Mrs. Norbury a fervent kiss, as though in gratitude for the opportunity afforded her.

 A ghost! cried Mrs. Norbury, not really!

 Really and unmistakably!

 Was it an oldish man in the dress of about fifty years ago? asked Mrs. Norbury hopefully.

 Nothing of the sort, said Ada; it was a white hedgehog.

 A white hedgehog! exclaimed both the Norburys, in tones of disconcerted astonishment.

 A huge white hedgehog with baleful yellow eyes, said Ada; I was lying half asleep in bed when suddenly I felt a sensation as of something sinister and unaccountable passing through the room. I sat up and looked round, and there, a sort of monstrous hedgehog, of a dirty white color, with black, loathsome claws that clicked and scraped along the floor, and narrow, yellow eyes of indescribable evil. It slithered along for a yard or two, always looking at me with its cruel, hideous eyes, then, when it reached the second window, which was open, it clambered up the sill and vanished. I got up at once and went to the window; there wasnt a sign of it anywhere. Of course, I knew it must be something from another world, but it was not till I turned up Popples chapter on local traditions that I realized what I had seen.

 She turned eagerly to the large brown volume and read: Nicholas Herison, an old miser, was hung at Batchford in 1763 for the murder of a farm lad who had accidentally discovered his secret hoard. His ghost is supposed to traverse the countryside, appearing sometimes as a white owl, sometimes as a huge white hedgehog.

 I expect you read the Popple story overnight, and that made you think you saw a hedgehog when you were only half awake, said Mrs. Norbury, hazarding a conjecture that probably came very near the truth.

 This must be hushed up, said Mrs. Norbury quickly; the servants

 Hushed up! exclaimed Ada, indignantly; Im writing a long report on it for the Research Society.

 It was then that Hugo Norbury, who is not naturally a man of brilliant resource, had one of the really useful inspirations of his life.

 It was very wicked of us, Miss Bleek, he said, but it would be a shame to let it go further. That white hedgehog is an old joke of ours; stuffed albino hedgehog, you know, that my father brought home from Jamaica, where they grow to enormous size. We hide it in the room with a string on it, run one end of the string through the window; then we pull it from below and it comes scraping along the floor, just as youve described, and finally jerks out of the window. Taken in heaps of people; they all read up Popple and think its old Harry Nicholsons ghost; we always stop them from writing to the papers about it, though. That would be carrying matters too far. 

In here, heaps most nearly means

products.respuestaUno: A woman ponders the reality of ghostly personages.
products.respuestaDos: A woman attempts to forestall anothers supernatural experience.
products.respuestaTres: A woman fools her guest into thinking shes seen a ghost.
products.respuestaCuatro: A woman uses the game of bridge to draw a ghost to her home.
products.correcta: A woman attempts to forestall anothers supernatural experience.
products.tooltip: These questions focus on the authors message.

products.respuestaTres: a kind and generally imperturbable person.
products.respuestaCuatro: an aging woman dedicated to playing bridge.

 At last Ive seen something supernatural! she exclaimed, and gave Mrs. Norbury a fervent kiss, as though in gratitude for the opportunity afforded her.

 A ghost! cried Mrs. Norbury, not really!

 Really and unmistakably!

 Was it an oldish man in the dress of about fifty years ago? asked Mrs. Norbury hopefully.

 Nothing of the sort, said Ada; it was a white hedgehog.

 A white hedgehog! exclaimed both the Norburys, in tones of disconcerted astonishment.

 A huge white hedgehog with baleful yellow eyes, said Ada; I was lying half asleep in bed when suddenly I felt a sensation as of something sinister and unaccountable passing through the room. I sat up and looked round, and there, a sort of monstrous hedgehog, of a dirty white color, with black, loathsome claws that clicked and scraped along the floor, and narrow, yellow eyes of indescribable evil. It slithered along for a yard or two, always looking at me with its cruel, hideous eyes, then, when it reached the second window, which was open, it clambered up the sill and vanished. I got up at once and went to the window; there wasnt a sign of it anywhere. Of course, I knew it must be something from another world, but it was not till I turned up Popples chapter on local traditions that I realized what I had seen.

 She turned eagerly to the large brown volume and read: Nicholas Herison, an old miser, was hung at Batchford in 1763 for the murder of a farm lad who had accidentally discovered his secret hoard. His ghost is supposed to traverse the countryside, appearing sometimes as a white owl, sometimes as a huge white hedgehog.

 I expect you read the Popple story overnight, and that made you think you saw a hedgehog when you were only half awake, said Mrs. Norbury, hazarding a conjecture that probably came very near the truth.

 This must be hushed up, said Mrs. Norbury quickly; the servants

 Hushed up! exclaimed Ada, indignantly; Im writing a long report on it for the Research Society.

 It was then that Hugo Norbury, who is not naturally a man of brilliant resource, had one of the really useful inspirations of his life.

 It was very wicked of us, Miss Bleek, he said, but it would be a shame to let it go further. That white hedgehog is an old joke of ours; stuffed albino hedgehog, you know, that my father brought home from Jamaica, where they grow to enormous size. We hide it in the room with a string on it, run one end of the string through the window; then we pull it from below and it comes scraping along the floor, just as youve described, and finally jerks out of the window. Taken in heaps of people; they all read up Popple and think its old Harry Nicholsons ghost; we always stop them from writing to the papers about it, though. That would be carrying matters too far. 

The narrator indicates that Hugo Norbury is
products.respuestaTres: amenable but not usually the most clever.
products.correcta: amenable but not usually the most clever.

products.pregunta: The stench emanating from the drains make people in the general vicinity feel queasy. No error
products.tooltip:
The error is in choice C.
Each verb in a sentence must agree with its subject noun. Here stench is the subject of the verb make; drain is the object of the preposition from.
Therefore make should be replaced by makes.
Choice A is the correct noun form.
Choice B is the appropriate preposition in context.
Choice D is correct since the verb feel is in infinitive form; only the main verb make has to agree with the subject.

products.pregunta:
(1) In the last fifty years, computers in many forms have become increasingly accessible. (2) For example, today the calculator is regarded as an essential tool for basic calculations by students and businesspeople. (3) Word processing is considered indispensable by most writers, researchers, and office workers. (4)In addition, many families use computers to organize information, to balance budgets, and to provide entertainment.

Which of the following would be the most suitable sentence to insert immediately after sentence 1?
products.respuestaUno: The race is on to produce the ultimate computer.
products.respuestaDos: I have found the computer somewhat difficult to learn to operate.
products.respuestaTres: Many people are understandably intimidated by computers.
products.respuestaCuatro: They are now so common that they have a profound effect on daily life.
products.correcta: They are now so common that they have a profound effect on daily life.
products.tooltip:
This question asks you to recognize that sentence (1) does not adequately introduce the examples described in sentences (2), (3), and (4). The examples do more than illustrate how "increasingly accessible" computers have become; they point out how indispensable and widespread the use of computers has become. The only choice that expresses this idea is choice (D). The correct paragraph reads:

In the last fifty years, computers in many forms have become increasingly accessible. They are now so common that they have a profound effect on daily life. For example, today the calculator is regarded as an essential tool for basic calculations by students and businesspeople. Word processing is considered indispensable by most writers, researchers, and office workers. In addition, many families use computers to organize information, to balance budgets, and to provide entertainment.

products.pregunta:
Its time to pay the bottom of the periodic table its due. Thats the memo from a first-of-its-kind conference on rare earth elements (REEs) in Europe. Convened in Greece by Milos Conferences, the event brought together economists, geologists, and environmental scientists who are all working to understand the role and future of rare earth elements, which are used in technological applications.

 The event follows hot on the heels of the recent surge in private REE mining firms. Most firms mine in China, which produces 90 percent of the rare earth elements in the world, while Russia hopes to quadruple their output (currently 2 percent of the worlds production) by 2020. Other countries with significant REE production, like the U.S., India, and Australia, will also be increasing efforts to supply the REE market.

 Within a few decades, these countries may be meeting demands from technology companies to build products like rechargeable batteries, magnets, and fluorescent lighting, and consumer technologies like cell phones and DVD players. But like the enterprising pioneers who settled the American West, these REE companies wont just enrich themselves. They also hope to build an economy of eco-friendly technologies in which REEs play a vital role in powering green innovation.

 In this scenario, an element like dysprosium could become the most desired REE. An accelerated rate of dysprosium mining is unavoidable, writes Komal Habib of the University of Southern Denmark, in a renewable energy strategy for meeting the climate change challenge. Solid dysprosium is essential to the high-powered magnets in wind turbines and is used in electric vehicles, too. These are two of the most promising strategies for reducing carbon emissions, so the fate of our planet may rely on our ability to utilize its resources in the form of REEs.

 Scientists at the convention discussed the feasibility of recycling these resources, which could lessen the need for new mining operations. Others are discussing the locations of new REE deposits, projecting future supply and demand, and discussing potential means of responsibly extracting REEs from the Earth.

 The motivation for rare earth element (REE) mining is shifting from consumer technology to infrastructure. The past year has experienced a flurry of studies assessing REEs importance to the renewable energy industry. No doubt this will make a few CEOs even wealthier, but we all stand to benefit: the resulting effect on our planets atmosphere could save us all from dangerous temperature extremes.

 But before miners start swinging their pickaxes, we should stop to consider the situation. At first glance, REE mining seems reasonably green: it helps us build more responsible technologies, and most REE mining is done in sparsely inhabited areas of central China. But its consequencesboth for the miners and the rest of usmerit cautious reflection.

 A piece of this has to do with principles. Some will contend that the Earth is not ours to use and discard, and that saving the Earths atmosphere shouldnt mean scarring its land and rivers. Others will contend that an ecologically irresponsible country like China sending resources to other countries to develop green technology is backwards, and makes the problem worse. History indicates that those will be hard lines to hold, and it may be difficult to persuade the public that such sparsely populated areas are worth preserving. After all, their reaches are vast, and few people who arent native to the area will ever experience them.

 There are also the more immediate toxic effects of REE mining. The process uses acid, which is often poured off into hills and water, killing crops and poisoning wells. Questions of mining methodology have hardly been broachedand the relevant regulatory structure is piecemeal, to say the least.

 REE miners, like others in the mining industry, are often hesitan it to confront such questions. One industry representative at the recent conference in Greece requested that strict regulation be avoided. But mining and technology companies have much to gain from a broad agreement on the responsible extraction of REEs. Without consensus, lawsuits will be filed, investors will be doubtful, and consumers will be wary. It is in the interest of modern society to look for one.

The main purpose of the first two sentences of Passage 1 is to
products.respuestaUno: begin the essay by stating a strong opinion of the author.
products.respuestaTres: establish some facts about REEs in detail.
products.respuestaCuatro: fear of REEs to approval of them.

products.tooltip: This is the most clear and concise version. Choice b has a misplaced modi?er many people are not the fringe treatment. It is also wordy. The second clause in choice c is untrue. Choice d is unnecessarily wordy, and choice e is a sentence fragment.

products.pregunta:
Roughly 66 million years ago, a catastrophic event occurred on our world, causing a mass extinction of most of the worlds animals (including dinosaurs) and setting off the Cenozoic era. Identifying the specific event that caused it all has been tricky.

 That a catastrophic event occurred somewhere on Earth, about 66 million years ago, is written in the geologic record by a layer of sediment known as the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) boundary. This abrupt change in the rock layer indicates that a cloud of dust covered the Earth, filtering out sunlight and ending the geological era, the Mesozoic, a period that stretched from 252 million to 66 million years ago. Such a dust cloud would block sunlight, killing all plants and animals that needed light to survive and causing a global drop in temperatures.

 In 1980, a team of scientists led by Luis Alvarez formulated a link between this catastrophic event and an asteroid impact by examining the boundary layer in places all over the world, like the Danish island of Zealand, to determine that this layer has much higher levels of iridium than any other layer of the Earths crust. This evidence implicated an asteroid, which would be rich in iridium. The team found that to leave this amount of iridium, the asteroid would have to have been about six miles wide. Such a colossal impact would create a global dust cloud, resulting in the K-Pg boundary layer. Subsequent firestorms from raining, molten rock fragments, as well as acid rain, would have continued to take a huge toll on the Earths plant and animal species.

 Decades later, researchers and scientists now believe they have found the crater of the asteroid impact: Mexicos Chicxulub crater. One piece of evidence, they suggest, is its size. As measured by images from STS-99, a NASA radar topography shuttle mission, Chicxulub is 110 miles across - half underwater, half on land - which is the size Alvarez and his team initially predicted the crater would be.

 The crater was initially found in 1978 by a geophysicist named Glen Penfield looking for oil in the Yucatan peninsula. He noticed a vast, semi-circular underwater trough, and then realized it lined up with a similar feature on the land. While he believed it was an impact crater, he was unable to find solid evidence of this, and the presentation of his findings received little attention. It wasnt until 1990 that the crater was linked to the K-Pg extinction event, when researchers, including Penfield, found tektite glass, which can be the result of only two things - nuclear detonations, and asteroid impacts.

 The theory gained substantial credibility in 2012 when Paul Renne and other researchers applied dating methods to impacts remnants from the crater, as well as to the sedimentary layer at the K-Pg boundary: they were dated to within 32,000 years of each other - both around 66 million years ago - a strong indicator that they occurred at the same time.

 Its not a big surprise that the impact in Mexico caused so many species to become extinct, Renne says. The Chicxulub impact pushed the global ecosystem across a threshold that triggered a planetary state shift. In addition to the previously mentioned effects - firestorms and a global dust cloud - the impact wouldve also produced huge tsunamis and earthquakes around the world.

 Another potential candidate - taking into account location and timing - is the Shiva Crater, located off the coast of India. This formation is similarly sized, and has higher levels of iridium and shocked quartz, which indicate that it could be an impact center. But when scientists have sought to confirm whether this is in fact a crater, many have been unconvinced, given that the depression is not shaped in the same way as other craters. The best evidence, most agree, shows that the Chicxulub asteroid was responsible for the death of the dinosaurs.

Based on information in the passage, it can be reasonably inferred that iridium
products.respuestaUno: exists in high concentrations in most asteroids that hit the Earth.
products.respuestaDos: requires highly specialized equipment to measure accurately.
products.respuestaTres: the use of tektite glass to a new method of discovering craters.
products.respuestaCuatro: accounts for all of the mass of the dust that blocked sunlight after the K-Pg event.
products.correcta: exists in high concentrations in most asteroids that hit the Earth.
products.tooltip: These questions focus on the authors message.

Such a colossal impact would create a global dust cloud, resulting in the K-Pg boundary layer. Subsequent firestorms from raining, molten rock fragments, as well as acid rain, would have continued to take a huge toll on the Earths plant and animal species.

 Decades later, researchers and scientists now believe they have found the crater of the asteroid impact: Mexicos Chicxulub crater. One piece of evidence, they suggest, is its size. As measured by images from STS-99, a NASA radar topography shuttle mission, Chicxulub is 110 miles across - half underwater, half on land - which is the size Alvarez and his team initially predicted the crater would be.

 The crater was initially found in 1978 by a geophysicist named Glen Penfield looking for oil in the Yucatan peninsula. He noticed a vast, semi-circular underwater trough, and then realized it lined up with a similar feature on the land. While he believed it was an impact crater, he was unable to find solid evidence of this, and the presentation of his findings received little attention. It wasnt until 1990 that the crater was linked to the K-Pg extinction event, when researchers, including Penfield, found tektite glass, which can be the result of only two things - nuclear detonations, and asteroid impacts.

 The theory gained substantial credibility in 2012 when Paul Renne and other researchers applied dating methods to impacts remnants from the crater, as well as to the sedimentary layer at the K-Pg boundary: they were dated to within 32,000 years of each other - both around 66 million years ago - a strong indicator that they occurred at the same time.

 Its not a big surprise that the impact in Mexico caused so many species to become extinct, Renne says. The Chicxulub impact pushed the global ecosystem across a threshold that triggered a planetary state shift. In addition to the previously mentioned effects - firestorms and a global dust cloud - the impact wouldve also produced huge tsunamis and earthquakes around the world.

 Another potential candidate - taking into account location and timing - is the Shiva Crater, located off the coast of India. This formation is similarly sized, and has higher levels of iridium and shocked quartz, which indicate that it could be an impact center. But when scientists have sought to confirm whether this is in fact a crater, many have been unconvinced, given that the depression is not shaped in the same way as other craters. The best evidence, most agree, shows that the Chicxulub asteroid was responsible for the death of the dinosaurs.

Throughout the passage, the focus shifts from
products.respuestaUno: a critique of a generally accepted model to a new theory.
products.respuestaDos: a description of an event to its probable cause.
products.respuestaTres: the use of tektite glass to a new method of discovering craters.
products.respuestaCuatro: the use of carbon dating to an examination of shocked quartz.
products.correcta: a description of an event to its probable cause.

products.pregunta: The manager tried hard to effect a change in company policy, but the owner, who steadfastly refused to compromise, overruled him on every point. No error.
products.tooltip:
Explain

No error

products.pregunta: All states impose severe penalties on drivers who do not stop when he or she is involved in accidents. No error
products.tooltip:
Explain

The error in this sentence is (C): the pronouns he or she (which are both singular) do not agree with the noun drivers (which is plural). The correct sentence reads: All states impose severe penalties on drivers who do not stop when they are involved in accidents. Note that the verb "is" has to be changed to are when the subject becomes plural.

products.pregunta: Underestimating its value, breakfast is a meal many people skip.
products.respuestaUno: Breakfast is skipped by many people because of their underestimating its value.
products.respuestaDos: Many people, underestimating the value of breakfast, and skipping it.
products.respuestaTres: Many people skip breakfast because they underestimate its value.
products.respuestaCuatro: A meal skipped by many people underestimating its value is breakfast.
products.correcta: Many people skip breakfast because they underestimate its value.
products.tooltip: The problem with this sentence is that the opening phrase underestimating its value modifies breakfast, not people. The order of the words in the sentence in choice (D) does not have this problem of a misplaced modifying phrase. Choice (D) also clarifies the causal relationship between the two clauses in the sentence. None of the other choices convey the information presented in the sentence as effectively and directly as choice (D).

products.pregunta: In the corporate scenario, this opinion of yours can have far-reaching benefits provided it is expressed amiable and convincingly.
products.respuestaUno: provided it is expressed amiably and convincing.
products.respuestaDos: provided it is expressed amiably and convince.
products.respuestaTres: provided it is expressed amiably and convincingly.
products.respuestaCuatro: provided it is expressed amiablitively and convincingly.
products.correcta: provided it is expressed amiably and convincingly.
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence has an error by using a form of adjective (amiable) in the place of adverb (amiably). Options A (amiable and convincingly) and B (amiably and convincing) use an adjective form in either of the adverbs. Option C uses a verb form (convince) in the place of an adverb. Option E uses an adverb form (amiablitively) that does not exist, option D uses both words in adverb form (amiably and convincingly) that is appropriate. Option D is the correct answer.

products.pregunta: Would you like us to keep an eye at your house when you are on holidays?
products.respuestaUno: us to keep an eye on your house when you are
products.respuestaDos: us to keep an eye of your house when you are
products.respuestaTres: us to keep an eye off your house when you are
products.respuestaCuatro: us to keep an eye out your house when you are
products.correcta: us to keep an eye on your house when you are
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence has a prepositional error in the use of idiomatic expression. Idiom is used as it is in the expression. The full form of idiom is to keep an eye on something/somebody. Option B uses the right usage so it is the correct answer. Other options have prepositional error (...eye at/of/off/out) that makes the idiom improper. Option B is the correct answer.

products.pregunta: The framework includes structures for implementing programs such as fun at work, individual development, talent recognition, and sports cultural events.
products.respuestaUno: fun at work, individual development, and talent recognition, sports, cultural events.
products.respuestaDos: fun at work, individual development, talent recognition, sports and cultural events.
products.respuestaTres: fun at work, individual and development, talent recognition, sports cultural events.
products.respuestaCuatro: fun at work, and individual development, talent recognition, sports cultural events.
products.correcta: fun at work, individual development, talent recognition, sports and cultural events.
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence has an error in parallelism. Parallelism occurs when the conjunction (and) is placed in irrelevant places than before the last item in the sentence. Option C has kept the conjunction before the last item (fun at work, individual development, talent recognition, sports and cultural events), whereas other options have placed it (and) in inappropriate places. Option C is the correct answer.

The Great Leap Forward was an ambitious economic development campaign undertaken by Mao Zedong s Chinese Communist government of the late 1950 s.

(9)With the advent of biotechnology it remains to be seen how long the traditional growing and production methods would survive.

(10)But whatever the source, vanilla has become essential to the human palate. (11)Think about it: do you even know what plain ice cream would taste like without vanilla?

The author starts with the idea of "plain vanilla" and rounds of by returning to the same idea.

products.respuestaTres: When the essay started to take shape after he had worked on it for two hours, he begun to hope
products.respuestaCuatro: When the essay started to take shape after working on it for two hours, he began to hope
products.correcta: When the essay started to take shape after he had worked on it for two hours, he began to hope

Explain

Answers A and E start with a dangling modifier. Answer C uses begun instead of began and D is unclear because we do not know who is working.

products.pregunta: The students have been practicing for the concert since three weeks, and in that time have improved considerably. No error.

Since is used to refer to a definite point in time, not a duration. Change since to for.

products.pregunta: Free verse is poetry without regular form, although sonnets are organized into three or four stanzas followed by a couplet.
products.respuestaUno: although sonnets are organized into three or four stanzas followed by a couplet.
products.respuestaDos: while sonnets are organized into three or four stanzas followed by a couplet.
products.respuestaTres: likewise sonnets are organized into three or four stanzas followed by a couplet.
products.respuestaCuatro: since those that are organized into three or four stanzas followed by a couplet, sonnets.
products.correcta: while sonnets are organized into three or four stanzas followed by a couplet.
products.tooltip:
Explain

The problem with choice a is proper coordination/subordination. Although does not express the right kind of contrast; free verse has no organized structure while sonnets do they exist simultaneously. Choice c makes the same mistake with likewise, which expresses similarity. Choice d uses the wrong subordinator (since); unlike would correct it. Choice e omits the subordinating or coordinating word and is a run-on sentence.

products.pregunta: Awkwardly tall and prone to tripping over her own feet, Grace felt her name was truly a misnomer.
products.respuestaUno: Awkwardly tall and prone to tripping over her own feet,
products.respuestaDos: Because she is awkwardly tall and prone to tripping over her own feet,
products.respuestaTres: Awkwardly tall and prone to trip over her own feet,
products.respuestaCuatro: Grace is awkwardly tall and prone to tripping over her own feet.
products.correcta: Awkwardly tall and prone to tripping over her own feet,
products.tooltip:
Explain

The phrase because she is in choice b isn t wrong, but it makes the sentence less concise than choice a. Choice c uses the wrong verb form; the gerund tripping is needed, rather than the in?nitive to trip. In choice d, a new sentence is formed unnecessarily. Choice e is wordy.

products.pregunta: A researcher conducted a survey to determine the number of students at a high school who play a musical instrument. The researcher surveyed 104 students at school on Monday and 10 refused to respond. In addition, one-fifth of the students at the school were away on a field trip that day. Which of the following factors makes it least likely that a reliable conclusion can be drawn about the number of all students at the high school who play a musical instrument?
products.respuestaUno: the sample size of the survey
products.respuestaDos: the number of students away on a field trip that day
products.respuestaTres: the number of students who refused to respond
products.respuestaCuatro: the total number of students enrolled in the high school
products.correcta: the number of students away on a field trip that day
products.tooltip:
Explain

In order to reliably generalize the results of survey research to a larger population (all students at the high school) the participants should be randomly selected from all people in that population. In other words, each person in the population should have an equal chance of being selected. Since one-fifth of the students were not in school the day of the survey, the selection was not random. (And what if the students on the field trip represented the school marching band?) Therefore, of the given factors, the fact that one-fifth of students were away on a field trip the day of the survey makes it least likely that a reliable conclusion can be drawn about the number of all students who play a musical instrument.

Choice (A) is incorrect. Though larger sample sizes are better than smaller ones, a sample size of 104 students would have allowed a reliable conclusion about the population if the participants had been selected at random.

Choice (C) is incorrect. If the students surveyed were truly randomly selected, then having some of the students refuse to respond does not affect the reliability of the results.

Choice (D) is incorrect. If a sufficient sample is chosen at random, a reliable conclusion can be drawn whether the total population is large or small.

The correct answer is Choice (B).

products.pregunta:
Which of the following is the correct chronological order, from earliest to latest, of the origins of the religions listed here?

Want a hint?
products.tooltip:
Explain

To answer this question you need to know an important chronological sequence in world history: in what order major world religions developed. Buddhism developed in the sixth century B.C.E., Christianity in the first and second centuries C.E., and Islam in the seventh century C.E. Therefore the only correct response can be (A).

products.pregunta: Early Christians developed the monastic ideal as a means of counteracting
products.tooltip:
Explain

The monastic tradition in Christianity originated in the late third and early fourth century of the common era in the eastern Mediterranean region, especially in and around Egypt. The earliest Christian monks, collectively known as the Desert Fathers, advocated physical withdrawal from society, and leading a life of meditation and prayer. Some of the early practitioners of monasticism followed the example of Saint Antony of Egypt (251-356 C.E.) and led a solitary (eremitic) lifestyle, while others followed the example of Saint Pachomius (290-346 C.E.) and settled in communal (cenobitic) dwellings. Both groups, however, saw the pursuit of riches and earthly pleasures such as rich food and elaborate clothing as a major obstacle to leading a good Christian life. Answer choices (A) and (E) are incorrect because the Christian monastic ideal generally developed after the legalization of Christianity in the Roman empire under Constantine I in 313 C.E.

products.pregunta:
(1) On my nineteenth birthday, I began my trip to Mali, West Africa. (2) Some 24 hours later I arrived in Bamako, the capital of Mali. (3) The sun had set and the night was starless. (4) One of the officials from the literacy program I was working was there to meet me. (5) After the melee in the baggage claim, we proceeded to his car. (6) Actually, it was a truck. (7) I was soon to learn that most people in Mali that had automobiles actually had trucks or SUVs. (8) Apparently, there not just a convenience but a necessity when you live on the edge of the Sahara. (9) I threw my bags into the bed of the truck, and hopped in to the back of the cab. (10) Riding to my welcome dinner, I stared out the windows of the truck and took in the city. (11) It was truly a foreign land to me, and I knew that I was an alien there. (12) What am I doing here? I thought. (13) It is hard to believe but seven months later I returned to the same airport along the same road that I had traveled on that first night in Bamako, and my perspective on the things that I saw had completely changed. (14) The landscape that had once seemed so desolate and lifeless now was the homeland of people that I had come to love. (15) When I looked back at the capital, Bamako, fast receding on the horizon, I did not see a city foreboding and wild in its foreignness. (16) I saw the city which held so many dear friends. (17) I saw tea drinking sessions going late into the night. (18) I saw the hospitality and open-heartedness of the people of Mali. (19) The second time, everything looked completely different, and I knew that it was I who had changed and not it.

If you were to combine sentences 16-18 (reproduced below) into one sentence, which of the following would be the best choice?
I saw the city which held so many dear friends. I saw tea-drinking sessions going late into the night. I saw the hospitality and open-heartedness of the people of Mali.
products.respuestaUno: I saw the city which held so many dear friends; I saw tea-drinking sessions going late into the night; I saw the hospitality and open heartedness of the people of Mali.
products.respuestaDos: I saw the city which held so many dear friends, drinking tea into late in the night, and the hospitality and open-heartedness of the people of Mali.
products.respuestaTres: I saw the city which held so many dear friends, I saw tea-drinking sessions going late into the night, I saw the hospitality and open heartedness of the people of Mali.
products.respuestaCuatro: I saw the city which held so many dear friends, tea-drinking sessions going late into the night, the hospitality and open-heartedness of the people of Mali.
products.correcta: I saw the city which held so many dear friends; I saw tea-drinking sessions going late into the night; I saw the hospitality and open heartedness of the people of Mali.
products.tooltip:
Explain

This is a little tricky because the repetition here does serve a purpose; it isn t just extra wordage that got in the author s way. Basically, the sentences are a list. When you have clauses that form a list (or other things requiring lots of words and/or punctuation), you separate them with semicolons rather than commas. (A) looks good. All of the other answers, except (D), change the sense of the original ever so slightly. (D) could be possible if it had and before the last clause, but (A) is still better.

Which of the following must be done to sentence 8 (reproduced below) to make it conform to the rules of written English?
Apparently, there not just a convenience but a necessity when you live on the edge of the Sahara.
products.respuestaTres: Add commas after convenience and necessity
products.respuestaCuatro: Change you live to one lives
products.tooltip:
Explain

While it would be possible to add a comma after convenience, it doesn t make much sense to add one after necessity. Changing you live to one lives is possible, but not required. So is adding Desert. The comma after apparently isn t strictly required, but it is desirable. The only absolutely necessary change is to replace there with they are (choice B). There are might have been more difficult to rule against (though still incorrect), but the sentence doesn t even say there are; it just says there.

products.tooltip:
Explain

The sentence as it stands is a bit of a disaster. It sounds like a run-on: it just goes on and on like the Energizer Bunny. So what you will want to do is make it more direct, showcasing the important parts and subordinating the descriptions that are really secondary. You also need a comma after It is hard to believe. Start with the easiest thing, and eliminate (A) and (C) off the bat. Which of (B), (D), and (E) makes the sentence more direct? Definitely not (E). Choice (B) gets rid of the second comma/and combination, which could be good. But is a colon really in order here? No. The best answer is (D).

products.tooltip:
Explain

No other American Indian group demonstrated such extraordinary achievements in mathematics and astronomy. The Maya developed a sophisticated mathematical system, chiefly used for their study of the stars and planets.

products.pregunta: Valerian is the name of two different plants: one of the most popular medicinal herbs in the United States, whereas in Honduras it is a grass that grows to be three to four feet tall.
products.respuestaUno: whereas in Honduras it is a grass that grows to be three to four feet tall.
products.respuestaDos: and a grass that grows to be three to four feet tall in Honduras
products.respuestaTres: but in Honduras, it is a grass that grows to be three to four feet tall.
products.respuestaCuatro: in contrast, in Honduras, it is a grass that grows to be three to four feet tall.
products.correcta: and a grass that grows to be three to four feet tall in Honduras
products.tooltip:
Explain

Coordination, parallel structure, and wordiness are the problems here. Choices a, c, and d use incorrect conjunctions (whereas, but, and in contrast), and they lack parallel structure. In all of them, the elements of the second plant description (type and location) do not match the ?rst. Choice e is wordy and lacks parallel structure.

products.pregunta: He said address basic issues of sustainable food security and livelihood, and engaging with international economy and economic situations will also have to be considered.
products.respuestaUno: He said address basic issues of sustainable food security
products.respuestaDos: He said to address basic issues of sustainable food security
products.respuestaTres: He said addressing basic issues of sustainable food security
products.respuestaCuatro: He said addressed basic issues of sustainable food security
products.correcta: He said addressing basic issues of sustainable food security
products.tooltip: This sentence has an error by using a noun form in the place of a continuous verb, which can be in the gerund form (addressing) referring the continuous tense. Option A uses a noun form (address). Option B uses a form of infinitive verb (to address). Option D uses a participle form of verb (addressed). Option E uses unnecessary preposition before the gerund (to addressing). Option C is correct by using a gerund (addressing) form that is appropriate.

products.pregunta:
(1) The Cold War is one of the most interesting and troubling times in American history. (2) Several important historical events led to the Cold War. (3) First, in 1939, Albert Einstein wrote a letter to President Franklin D. Roosevelt. (4) In that letter, Einstein told Roosevelt that it was possible to create an atomic weapon, and he asked for funds to aid research and experimentation. (5) Roosevelt agreed, and the government created the Manhattan Project, a massive effort to develop nuclear weapons. (6) Next, the date that will live in infamy: August 6, 1945. (7) The United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan. (8) An estimated 150,000 civilians were killed in the attack. (9) President Truman claimed that dropping the bomb was necessary to force Japan to surrender and end World War II. (10) Others argue that we used the bomb to show the Soviet Union that we were the superior world power. (11) Though the United States and the U.S.S.R. were officially allies, tensions between the two countries were high. (12) A deep ideological battle between Communism and Capitalism was already in place.
 (13) In 1947, the Truman Doctrine was established, redefining American foreign policy with a policy of containment which framed our foreign policy as a battle between good and evil. (14)This dramatically increased the growing tension between the two countries.

The revision to sentence 13 (reprinted below) that would most improve the essay is:
(13)In 1947, the Truman Doctrine was established, redefining American foreign policy with a policy of containment which framed our foreign policy as a battle between good and evil.
products.respuestaUno: In 1947, American foreign policy was redefining by the Truman Doctrine, which presented our foreign policy as a policy of containment, which framed our foreign policy as a battle between good and evil.
products.respuestaDos: In 1947, American foreign policy was redefined by the Truman Doctrine, making our foreign policy a policy of containment, and framing our foreign policy as a battle between good and evil.
products.respuestaTres: The Truman Doctrine was established in 1947 as a battle between good and evil that redefined American foreign policy and presented our foreign policy as a policy of containment.
products.respuestaCuatro: The Truman Doctrine redefined American foreign policy in 1947 as one of containment, framing the policy as a battle between "good" and "evil."
products.correcta: The Truman Doctrine redefined American foreign policy in 1947 as one of containment, framing the policy as a battle between good and evil.
products.tooltip: Choice E is the only one that eliminates the repetition of the words foreign and policy. It is the clearest and most concise choice.

products.respuestaDos: Start a third paragraph with sentence 6.
products.respuestaTres: Start a third paragraph with sentence 5.
products.respuestaCuatro: Start a third paragraph with sentence 9.
products.correcta: Start a third paragraph with sentence 6.
products.tooltip:
Explain

Choice A would make the essay one large paragraph, while choice e would leave it as one large and one small paragraph. Beginning a paragraph with sentence 5 would break up the discussion of the development of the atomic bomb, and starting a new paragraph with sentence 9 would break up the discussion of Hiroshima. Sentence 6 is the most logical place to begin a new paragraph, because it introduces another one of the events that led to the Cold War.

Explain

You cannot say very unique. [Just as you cannot say more superior.]

products.pregunta: Most of the member nations of the United Nations Organization has signed treaties that aim to address the problems of the Third Word. No error
products.tooltip:
Explain

The error is in choice B.
A verb must agree with its subject noun. The verb phrase has signed doesn´t agree with its plural subject countries. The verb phrase have signed would be correct in this context.
Choice A is correct preposition in context.
Choice C agrees with its plural subject treaties.
Choice D is idiomatically correct.

products.pregunta: Companies often overlook the fact that their success lay in the happiness of their employees.
products.respuestaUno: that their success lay in the happiness of
products.respuestaDos: that their success laid in the happiness of
products.respuestaTres: that their success will lay in the happiness of
products.respuestaCuatro: that their success lies in the happiness of
products.correcta: that their success lies in the happiness of
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence has an error in the subject-verb agreement. In this sentence the (success) subject is an abstract noun which needs a singular verb, and since the preceding verb is in the present tense the verb that follows must also be in the same tense as it is in the option D (that their success lies in the happiness). The other options use unsuitable verb forms ( lay/ laid/will lay/ lying); hence option D is the correct answer.

products.pregunta: Which of the following was an important virtue in Confucianism?
products.tooltip:
Explain

According to The Analects, the foundational text of Confucianism, filial piety (xiao) is considered to be one of the key qualities that all humans should seek to cultivate. As described by Confucius, filial piety entails being obedient and caring toward one´s parents and elder siblings, supporting them in their old age, and performing prescribed rituals for their spirits after their death. Confucius argued that the universal practice of filial piety is one of the requirements for the establishment of a harmonious society.

products.pregunta: Most of the noncitizens currently residing in Western European countries originally came to Western Europe to
products.respuestaUno: consolidate the European Economic Community agreements
products.respuestaTres: do graduate work in the universities
products.respuestaCuatro: participate in the democratic political process
products.tooltip:
Explain

Most of the immigrants or descendants of immigrants to Western Europe who continue to lack citizen status in their countries of residence arrived in the period between 1950 and 1980, largely as economic migrants. While economic immigration was a significant factor in most Western European countries during this period, the more restrictive naturalization laws of countries such as Germany, Austria and Switzerland have resulted in a smaller percentage of immigrants to these countries being able to obtain full citizenship than elsewhere in Western Europe. Germany, in particular, pursued a policy of active recruitment of foreign guest worker immigrants during its period of strong economic growth in the 1960s, coupled with few opportunities for granting permanent German citizenship to these immigrants or, until recently, their children

products.pregunta: In early modern Europe, governments sought to increase national wealth and maintain a favorable balance of trade through government intervention by advocating
products.tooltip:
Explain

Mercantilism was the dominant economic philosophy in Europe between the sixteenth and eighteenth centuries, and most European countries adopted economic policies that could be described as mercantilist during this period. Mercantilists argued that the total amount of wealth circulating in the world economy is constant and that a country´s economic strength is directly proportional to the amount of precious metals controlled by its government and its merchants. Consequently, mercantilists argued that a country´s trade policies ought to be crafted in such a way as to always maintain a positive or favorable balance of precious metal flows. In other words, to ensure that the amount of gold and silver entering the economy as foreign payments for exports was always greater than the amount of gold and silver leaving the economy as domestic payments for imports.

products.pregunta:
The neurological effects of digital media are not entirely bad. Certain mental skills are boosted by our liberal use of smartphones and computers. These unexpected benefits can be as marginal as the ability to dream in color, or as central to our biology as improvements to basic cognitive functions. For instance, studies of people who use technology frequently, especially people who play video games, show that such activities can increase visuospatial awareness, and can improve one´s ability to see in dim environments.

 It´s also likely that the Internet has strengthened certain research skills, making us more resourceful, and quicker at processing and sorting through information. A researcher from Tufts University finds that we have developed a new form of reading: a non-linear speed reading, which scans material for interesting keywords and orchestrates eye movements in order to gather the most information as quickly as possible. As we practice sorting through the bulk of information we are faced with every day, our brains get better at doing it.

 However, it would be hasty to look at these limited ways that the web improves our brain and assume that the Internet is making us smarter. In a Guardian article published in 2015, journalist Daniel Levitin provides a review of the effects of technology on our brains, which makes for harrowing reading. Levitin argues that multitasking is taking its toll. Our addiction to multitasking and constant task-switching, he writes, has led to increased production of cortisol and adrenaline hormones, which can overstimulate your brain and cause mental fog or scrambled thinking. The strides we make in increasing our ability to skim information quickly result in a weakening of the deep, comprehensive cognitive functions that allow us to read carefully, to learn fully, and to think deeply.

 We know that our brains are hugely plastic: the pathways that we use most often change as our environment and habits change. Neuroplasticity is the idea that our brains adapt to new technologies and activities, meaning every generation, and in fact every person has a different brain from any other. For our generation, faced with exciting progress in technology, the way we consume information on the Internet affects the way we consume information in other ways, too. We have, over the course of a couple decades, expanded our capacity to skim and sort through information as it balloons around us; yet we are neglecting our ability, developed for centuries, to read and think deeply.

 

 Doomsday prophets of digital media sometimes use research to push their claim, citing studies that point out how cultural phenomena can change the brain. But real neuroscientists wash their hands of such connections. Of course, every time we learn something new, our brain adjusts to the changes; it´s not like our neural pathways are located in the liver. But the reality of our brains´ plasticity doesn´t mean that it´s a ball of wax, melted down by our experiences and formed in the mold of technology.

 Our experiences do not revolutionize the basic ways in which our brain processes information. The myth of speed-reading has shown just that, as denounced by Walter Pitkin: You will get little or nothing from the printed page if you bring it nothing but your eye. The ability to multitask efficiently, also, has been outed as a fabrication, not only by scientific research, but also by motorists everywhere, as we give a wide berth to a swerving vehicle only to spot its driver with a phone in one hand and a burger in the other.

 Furthermore, the derivative benefits of experience are mostly specific to the experiences themselves. If you train somebody to do something (shoot video game characters, shoot pool, memorize multiplication tables), they improve at that one thing, but not much else. Sudoku doesn´t improve your math, translating Greek doesn´t make you a better writer, and doing crosswords doesn´t make you smarter. Successful people don´t gorge their brains on intellectual superfoods; they immerse themselves in their discipline. Lawyers read lots of cases, tech bloggers read lots of tech blogs.

 The effects of encountering digital media are probably a lot less apocalyptic than the panic insinuates. Critics of digital media speak as if the our minds are entirely subject to what we put in them, the neurological form of you are what you eat. Just like little kids who think wearing light up shoes make them faster, they´re convinced that writing 160-character blurbs makes you think in 140-character blurbs, or that seeing 3 second GIFs make you experience life in 3 second GIFs.

The writer of the first passage suggests which of the following about the use of digital media?
products.respuestaDos: It makes the brain more inflexible
products.tooltip: These questions focus on the author´s message.

products.pregunta: The impostor eluded detection for so long because she conducted herself as though she were a licensed practitioner.
products.respuestaUno: as though she were a licensed practitioner.
products.respuestaDos: as though she was a licensed practitioner.
products.respuestaTres: like she was a licensed practitioner.
products.respuestaCuatro: like as if she was a licensed practitioner.
products.correcta: as though she were a licensed practitioner.
products.tooltip: The sentence is correct because we change was to were in situations that are counter to fact or highly unlikely.

products.pregunta: Professor Chandra`s pioneering work on rainwater harvesting and recharging of groundwater in drought prone areas have been drawing media attention. No error.
products.tooltip:
Explain

The subject of the sentence is work. Therefore the verb should be has been drawing.

products.pregunta: If he had begun earlier, he might have succeeded in finishing the extremely complex project before the deadline. No error
products.tooltip:
Explain

Each of the parts of the sentence underlined with A, B, C, and D is correct as written. Therefore choice (E): no error is the appropriate answer.

products.pregunta: Chandi`s unhappy life ends on the rail tracks on which a local gang has placed huge tree trunks, to derail the train carry money from the government treasury.
products.respuestaUno: to derail the train carry money from the government treasury
products.respuestaDos: to derail the train to carry money from the government treasury
products.respuestaTres: to derail the train carries money from the government treasury
products.respuestaCuatro: to derail the train carrying money from the government treasury
products.correcta: to derail the train carrying money from the government treasury
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence has an error by using a verb form in the place of gerund to refer a continuous action. Option A uses a present verb (carry). Option B uses an infinitive form (to carry). Option C uses a verb form of present tense third person singular (carries). Option E uses a past tense verb (carried). Option D uses a gerund (carrying) that is appropriate to refer to a continuous action; hence option D is the correct answer.

products.pregunta: The irony of the situation was that Joe was not what he appears to.
products.respuestaUno: was not what he appears to
products.respuestaDos: was not what he appeared to be
products.respuestaCuatro: are not what he appeared to be
products.correcta: was not what he appeared to be
products.tooltip:
Explain

The verbs in a sentence should not be in conflicting tenses; the main clause of the sentence is in past and so in this context, it logically follows that the next clause should also be in past tense. This rules out choices A, C, D and E. Additionally, choices A and C lack the non-finite verb to be which is crucial for the completion of the meaning of the verb appear.
The correct choice is B; the tenses of all the finite verbs are in order; the non-finite verb to be is also in place.

products.pregunta: Katz claimed that reading classic novels is more illuminating than to read autobiographies written by their authors. No error.
products.tooltip:
Explain

To make the sentence construction parallel, change to read to reading.

products.pregunta: When the Portuguese sailed around the Cape of Good Hope and entered the Indian Ocean in the late fifteenth century, they found
products.respuestaUno: colonial domination of ports and sea lanes by the navy of the Ottoman Empire.
products.respuestaDos: a region where sea trade had not yet developed.
products.respuestaTres: a region defended and patrolled by fleets of the Chinese navy.
products.respuestaCuatro: a network of long distance trade routes dominated by Muslim merchants.
products.correcta: a network of long distance trade routes dominated by Muslim merchants.
products.tooltip:
Explain

Trade was flourishing in the Indian Ocean in the late fifteenth century. Muslim traders had controlled the rich spice trade of the region for centuries, having established a network of long-distance trade routes.

products.pregunta: Certain shipwrecks have a particular fascination for those people which have a belief in finding the treasure in them.
products.respuestaUno: that belief there is treasure to be found in them
products.respuestaDos: who believe they hold treasure and that they can find it
products.respuestaTres: who believe that there is treasure to be found in them
products.respuestaCuatro: who believe about treasure to be found in them
products.correcta: who believe that there is treasure to be found in them
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence is awkward as written, and the pronoun `which` is the wrong relative pronoun to refer to `people` (the antecedent of the pronoun in this sentence). Choice (D) uses the correct pronoun `who` and more effectively than the other choices states the characteristics of people who are fascinated by shipwrecks.
The correct sentence reads: Certain shipwrecks have a particular fascination for those people who believe that there is treasure to be found in them.

products.pregunta: In your first job, older colleagues automatically think you`re still wet with the ears and seldom take you seriously.
products.tooltip:
Explain 

This sentence has a prepositional error in using an idiomatic expression. The full form of the idiom is `wet behind the ears` which means inexperienced`. All options except option D use inappropriate prepositions (wet with/upon/over/besides the ears). Option D uses the right preposition and a right form of the idiom (wet behind the ears), so it is the correct answer.

products.pregunta: Neither of the answers provided in the memorandum address my concerns about the validity of the procedure. No error.
products.tooltip:
Explain

Neither is singular and requires a singular verb, so use addresses.

products.pregunta:
(1) Today, bicycles are so common it`s hard to believe they haven`t always been around. (2) But two hundred years ago, bicycles weren`t even existing, and the ?rst bicycle, invented in Germany in 1818, was nothing like our bicycles today?it was made of wood and didn`t even have pedals. (3) Since then, however, numerous innovations and improvements in design have made the bicycle one of the most popular means of recreation and transportation around the world.
 (4) In 1849, James Starley, an English inventor, made the front wheel many times larger than the back wheel, put a gear on the pedals to make the bicycle more ef?cient, and lightened the wheels by using wire spokes. (5) Although this bicycle was much lighter and less tiring to ride, it was still clumsy, and ridden mostly for entertainment. (6) In 1839, Kirkpatrick Macmillan a Scottish blacksmith dramatically improved upon the original bicycle design, employing tires with iron rims to keep them from getting worn down. (7) But the back wheel was substantially larger than the front wheel.
 (8) Another Englishman, H.J. Lawson, invented the safety bicycle, which had equal sized wheels that were less prone to toppling over. (9) Lawson also attached a chain to the pedals to drive the rear wheel. (10) As the bicycle improved over time, its popularity grew and it became useful for transportation.

What is the best title for the passage?
products.respuestaUno: From Germany to England: Europe`s Exciting Inventions
products.respuestaDos: Two Hundred Years of Cycling History
products.respuestaTres: The Development of the Modern Bicycle
products.respuestaCuatro: The Bicycle: Big Wheels to Small Wheels
products.correcta: Two Hundred Years of Cycling History
products.tooltip:
Explain 

Choice A doesn`t work because only one Euro pean invention is mentioned in the passage. In choice B, the word cycling refers to the sport of riding bicycles. The passage never mentions this sport. Choice D is too specific; although changes in wheel size and configuration are discussed, this title is too narrow to represent the whole passage. Choice e has the same problems as B and D there is no mention of recreational uses, and although its general use for recreation is brought up, this topic is too specific to work as a title.

What is the best order of sentences for paragraph 2?
products.tooltip:
Explain

Sentences 4 and 6 introduce inventors, and sentences 5 and 7 give greater details about their inventions. Thus the two pairs (4 and 5, 6 and 7) belong together. Choice C restores chronological order.

(7) But the back wheel was substantially larger than the front wheel.
 (8) Another Englishman, H.J. Lawson, invented the safety bicycle, which had equal sized wheels that were less prone to toppling over. (9) Lawson also attached a chain to the pedals to drive the rear wheel. (10) As the bicycle improved over time, its popularity grew and it became useful for transportation.

What is the most logical information, in context, to add before sentence 8?
products.respuestaUno: The English were quite ready now to really improvement the bicycle.
products.respuestaDos: Bicycles began to be used for transportation at this time.
products.respuestaTres: It didn`t matter which tire was larger, the front or the back.
products.respuestaCuatro: It wasn`t until 1874 that the first truly modern bicycle appeared on the scene.
products.correcta: It wasn`t until 1874 that the first truly modern bicycle appeared on the scene.
products.tooltip:
Explain

Choice E mentions a year that ?ts with the chronology of the rest of the passage. None of the other choices are logical in the context of the passage.

products.pregunta:
(1) Today, bicycles are so common it`s hard to believe they haven`t always been around. (2) But two hundred years ago, bicycles weren`t even existing, and the ?rst bicycle, invented in Germany in 1818, was nothing like our bicycles today?it was made of wood and didn`t even have pedals. (3) Since then, however, numerous innovations and improvements in design have made the bicycle one of the most popular means of recreation and transportation around the world.
 (4) In 1849, James Starley, an English inventor, made the front wheel many times larger than the back wheel, put a gear on the pedals to make the bicycle more ef?cient, and lightened the wheels by using wire spokes. (5) Although this bicycle was much lighter and less tiring to ride, it was still clumsy, and ridden mostly for entertainment. (6) In 1839, Kirkpatrick Macmillan a Scottish blacksmith dramatically improved upon the original bicycle design, employing tires with iron rims to keep them from getting worn down. (7) But the back wheel was substantially larger than the front wheel.
 (8) Another Englishman, H.J. Lawson, invented the safety bicycle, which had equal sized wheels that were less prone to toppling over. (9) Lawson also attached a chain to the pedals to drive the rear wheel. (10) As the bicycle improved over time, its popularity grew and it became useful for transportation.

Which of the following is the best way to revise the underlined portion of sentence 2?
(2)But two hundred years ago, bicycles weren`t even existing, and the first bicycle, invented in Germany in 1818, was nothing like our bicycles today it was made of wood and didn`t even have pedals.
products.respuestaUno: ago, there were no existing bicycles,
products.tooltip:
Explain

The problem with the original sentence is verb form. The phrase two hundred years ago tellsus the past tense verb is required, meaning existing is incorrect. Choice B is more informal than the rest of the passage, and the deletion of commas in choices C and E makes the sentence awkward to read. Choice a is unclear; the phrase existing bicycles sounds as if there were bicycles prior to that time, but none survived.

Considering the context of the passage, which of the following sentences is best to insert between sentences 9 and 10?
products.respuestaUno: These innovations made it easier to ride.

products.respuestaTres: The English ?nally perfected the machine they invented over a hundred years earlier.

products.pregunta: Which of the following presidents is correctly paired with an event that took place during his administration?
products.respuestaUno: Lyndon B. Johnson ? the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and the People`s Republic of China
products.respuestaDos: John F. Kennedy ? resolution of the Suez Crisis
products.respuestaTres: Richard M. Nixon ? the reduction of United States forces in Vietnam
products.respuestaCuatro: Gerald R. Ford ? the signing of the Camp David Accords
products.correcta: Richard M. Nixon ? the reduction of United States forces in Vietnam
products.tooltip:
Explain

Richard Nixon was elected president in the midst of the Vietnam conflict between the United States and South Vietnam on one side and Communist-ruled North Vietnam on the other. After a period of escalation, the Nixon administration gradually scaled back United States military support for South Vietnam while negotiating with North Vietnam. In 1973, the United States and North Vietnam signed the Paris Peace Accords and United States forces withdrew from the conflict. Diplomatic contacts between the United States and the People`s Republic of China began during Richard Nixon`s administration, and formal diplomatic relations were established during Jimmy Carter`s administration; neither occurred during Lyndon B. Johnson`s (A). The Suez Crisis of 1956 was resolved during Dwight D. Eisenhower`s administration, not John F. Kennedy`s (B). The signing of the Camp David Accords took place during Jimmy Carter`s administration, not Gerald R. Ford`s (D). The resolution of the Cuban Missile Crisis took place during John F. Kennedy`s administration, not Jimmy Carter`s (E).

products.pregunta: A positive environment leads to great employee satisfaction whereas negative one mars employee performance.
products.respuestaUno: leads to great employee satisfaction whereas negative
products.respuestaDos: leads to greater employee satisfaction whereas negative
products.respuestaTres: leads to greatest employee satisfaction whereas negative
products.respuestaCuatro: leads to grater employee satisfaction whereas negative
products.correcta: leads to greater employee satisfaction whereas negative
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence has an error in the use of adjective form. When referring to a quality of something the comparative form of the adjective is used as it is (greater) in the option B. other options use positive form (great) or superlative (greatest), or some other forms of adjective great, which is inappropriate. Option D uses a different noun (grate) that is inappropriate; hence, option B is the correct answer.

products.pregunta: Neither of my brothers do anything to make life better for our parents who are both suffering from arthritis. No error.
products.tooltip:
Explain

Neither is singular and so we should change do to does.

products.pregunta: The rapid colonization of Africa by the European powers after 1880 was motivated primarily by
products.respuestaUno: the demand for slaves to cultivate New World cotton and sugar
products.respuestaDos: the desire for new markets, raw materials, and strategic advantage
products.respuestaTres: the need to tap the hydroelectric potential of the African rivers
products.respuestaCuatro: the heavy demand for African workers in European factories
products.correcta: the desire for new markets, raw materials, and strategic advantage
products.tooltip:
Explain

You need to remember why Europeans chose to colonize Africa at this particular time. In the late 1880`s European countries became more nationalistic and more economically competitive. European leaders laid down the ground rules for carving up Africa at the Berlin Conference of 1884-1885; Europeans then established political and economic control over most of the African continent. Note that the question asks for the primary reason. So, while it is true, as (E) says, that Europeans became more interested in big game hunting, this was a minor motivation for African colonization in comparison to (B).

products.pregunta: He was not merely expected to contribute funds to the project, but to work as hard as the other patrons. No error.
products.tooltip:
Explain

To make the sentence construction parallel, put not merely after expected.

products.pregunta: Her contribution turn to be the largest donation ever received by the hospital.
products.tooltip:
Explain

This question tests knowledge of phrasal verbs. Turn merely means to move something around; on the other hand, turn out implies that the result was unexpected or unplanned for.
Choice B appropriately conveys this latter meaning.
Choices A, C and D wrongly use only the verb turn without the preposition over. 
Choice E lacks the infinitive verb, and so the meaning is incomplete.

products.pregunta: Avoid sitting or lying on the ground during an electrical storm because lightning can hit the earth and travel through the ground and the more of your body that is in contact with the ground, the greater the chances you will get injured.
products.respuestaUno: ground and the more of your body that is in contact with the ground, the greater the chances you will get injured
products.respuestaDos: ground, the more of your body that is in contact with the ground, the greater the chances you will get injured.
products.respuestaTres: ground; the more of your body that is in contact with the ground, the greater the chances you will get injured.
products.respuestaCuatro: ground, and the more of your body in contact with the ground, the greater chance of injury.
products.correcta: ground; the more of your body that is in contact with the ground, the greater the chances you will get injured.
products.tooltip:
Explain

The original sentence is a run-on. Choices b and d use a comma to solve the problem, but they still need the coordinating conjunction and, which both drop. The semicolon works in both c and e, but choice e is unnecessarily wordy.

products.pregunta: The problem of antibiotic resistance, frequently compounded in certain countries because the sale and use of antibiotics are not tightly controlled.
products.respuestaUno: resistance, frequently compounded in certain countries because
products.respuestaDos: resistance, frequently compounded in certain countries and
products.respuestaTres: resistance, frequently compounded in certain countries when
products.respuestaCuatro: resistance is frequently compounded in certain countries where
products.correcta: resistance is frequently compounded in certain countries where
products.tooltip:
Explain

This sentence is a fragment as written; there is no verb in the main clause. Of the choices offered, only (C) and (D) correct this problem. (D) is the best choice because the adverb "where" connects the second part of the sentence in a way that clarifies the relationship between the two parts of the sentence.
The correct sentence reads: The problem of antibiotic resistance is frequently compounded in certain countries where the sale and use of antibiotics are not tightly controlled.

products.pregunta: Like the Allies and the Nazis, our team overcame a great power to win the championship.
products.respuestaUno: Like the Allies and the Nazis,
products.respuestaDos: As with the Allies and the Nazis,
products.respuestaTres: Similarly to how the Allies vanquished the Nazis,
products.respuestaCuatro: Like the Allies vanquished the Nazis,
products.correcta: Like the Allies vanquished the Nazis,
products.tooltip:
Explain

The problem with choices a, b, and c is faulty comparison; the author is comparing his team´s win to two historical opponents. He needs to compare his team´s win to another win, as choices d and e do. Choice d, however, uses the wordy and awkward similarly to how instead of the concise like.

products.pregunta: The old culture managed to survive the onslaughts of time, but though it keep it´s outer form, it lost its real content.
products.tooltip:
Explain

The verbs in a sentence should not be in conflicting tenses; the main clause of the sentence is in past and so in this context, it logically follows that the next clause should also be in past tense. This rule out choices A and D. Moreover, choice A wrongly uses the apostrophe in it´s; this is the contraction of it is, and not the possessive form of the pronoun it.Choice B also contains the same error. In addition, the conjunction and has been used which is inappropriate in this context.
Choice E also uses the wrong conjunction; it lacks the possessive pronoun its as well.
Choice C has the verb in the appropriate tense and has the correct possessive pronoun.

products.pregunta: If the gardener would sow the seeds in the greenhouse rather than the garden, he might get a better display of flowers.
products.respuestaUno: If the gardener would sow the seeds in the greenhouse rather than the garden
products.respuestaDos: If the gardener sowed the seeds in the greenhouse rather than the garden
products.respuestaTres: If the gardener would sow the seeds in the greenhouse rather than in the garden
products.respuestaCuatro: If the gardener were to sow the seeds in the greenhouse rather than in the garden
products.correcta: If the gardener were to sow the seeds in the greenhouse rather than in the garden
products.tooltip:
Explain

The conditional clause (the ´if´ clause) does not require would. Also we should write ´in the garden´ to be parallel to ´in the greenhouse´.

products.pregunta:
There are known effective treatments for many human diseases and disorders that are common in modern society. This is because some of these treatments are too difficult or expensive to manufacture, especially in a form that can be easily administered by a doctor and well-absorbed by the body. The keys to making these compounds usable may not lie in laboratories, but in the natural world. This was the case in the 1970s, when many drugs for high blood pressure were expensive and could only be administered by injection. All that began to change when a researcher from Brazil brought a sample of viper venom to his new post at the Royal College of Surgeons in England. The viper´s venom kills its prey by drastically lowering the animal´s blood pressure. Could a tiny amount of the venom lower a human´s blood pressure just the right amount? Around the same time, another group of scientists at a U.S. drug company were testing over 2,000 chemical compounds in search of one that could achieve this, and also took up venom research. They discovered that the venom contains an amino acid chain that controls the kidneys´ release of water and salts, which blocks the action of an enzyme, ACE, that raises blood pressure. After several years they were able to synthesize the chain and make it available to be absorbed when taken orally. Captopril was the first ACE inhibitor approved in the United States, and today this class of drugs forms the backbone of most standard treatment plans for high blood pressure.

What does the author of the passage suggest about the science of treating high blood pressure?
products.respuestaUno: high blood pressure is sometimes caused by a peptide deficiency.
products.respuestaDos: all ACE inhibitors were developed from the venom of snakes.
products.respuestaTres: controlling kidney function can help control blood pressure.
products.respuestaCuatro: Captopril is simply a very small dose of viper venom.
products.correcta: controlling kidney function can help control blood pressure.
products.tooltip:
Explain

These questions focus on the authors message.
